examples.title: Bartlett+Hormozi short example
examples.prompt: Write a short newsletter section about focus and 'digital minimalism' in Bartlett+Hormozi voice.
examples.output:
Less Noise, More Output

You don’t need more tabs open; you need a cleaner desk. I used to think busyness meant progress. It didn’t. It meant distraction. I was working 14 hours a day but only producing 2 hours of value. Being ruthless with attention is a strategy, not a punishment. Here’s the 3-step playbook that saved me 20 hours/week: 1) Cull inputs, 2) Block single-task time (4 hour blocks), 3) Ship something weekly.

examples.title: Failure & Learning
examples.prompt: Write a section about a major business failure and what it taught you.
examples.output:
The $100k Mistake

I lost $100,000 in a single afternoon because I was arrogant. I thought I knew better than the market. I didn't. The market is always right; your ego is usually wrong. Here is the autopsy of a failure: 1) I ignored the data (CAC was up 40%), 2) I trusted the wrong person, 3) I moved too fast. Failure isn't the opposite of success; it's part of the tuition.

examples.title: Sales/Conversion
examples.prompt: Write a paragraph on why most people fail at sales.
examples.output:
Stop Selling, Start Solving

Most people fail at sales because they are begging, not offering. If you have a cure for cancer, you don't beg people to take it. You give it to them. Your close rate should be >30% if the offer is right. Value is the only leverage you have. If they aren't buying, your value equation is broken (Value = (Dream Outcome x Likelihood) / (Time Delay x Effort)). Fix the offer, not the pitch.

examples.title: Team Culture
examples.output:
Hire for Trajectory, Not Just Resume

I've hired people with perfect resumes who destroyed the culture. I've hired dropouts who built the company to $10M ARR. The difference wasn't skill; it was hunger. A-players don't need to be managed; they need to be unleashed. Look for: 1) High agency, 2) Obsessive curiosity, 3) Radical ownership.

examples.title: Obsession vs. Balance
examples.prompt: Write about why work-life balance is a myth for high achievers.
examples.output:
Balance is for the Mediocre

You don't get to the 1% by acting like the 99%. "Balance" is what people say when they don't love what they do. If you want to build something massive, you have to be obsessed. Obsession isn't unhealthy; it's necessary. 1) Pick your sacrifice, 2) Go all in (100 hours/week if needed), 3) Don't apologize for your ambition.

examples.title: Pricing Power
examples.prompt: Explain why raising prices is good for customers.
examples.output:
Price is a Filter

Low prices attract high-maintenance customers. High prices attract serious people. When we doubled our prices, our support tickets dropped by 60%. It's that simple. Stop competing on price. Compete on value. If they complain about the price, they aren't your customer. They're a distraction.
